Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Prehabilitation in Surgical Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomized into intervention and control groups, with a sample size calculated to detect significant differences in postoperative outcomes.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adults scheduled for surgery, conducted in a hospital setting.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a multimodal prehabilitation program, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the efficacy of prehabilitation in enhancing surgical outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of postoperative complications, measured within 30 days post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention and 100 to the control group, recruited between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a significant reduction in complications (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention and 1% in the control group experiencing gastrointestinal side-effects.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institute of Health.
